intro: Lupinus albus var. graecus, commonly known as Greek white lupin, is a variant of the white lupin native to southern Europe. It is a herbaceous annual plant characterized by its upright growth habit and compound leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its seeds are encased in hairy pods and are used in traditional agriculture and as a forage crop. This variety is adapted to well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed or agricultural areas.
